questions.questionsTitle: Base of a triangle is 9 and height is 5. Base of another triangle is 10 and height is 6. Find the ratio of areas of these triangles.

subQuestion.question: Base of a triangle is 9 and height is 5. Base of another triangle is 10 and height is 6. Find the ratio of areas of these triangles.
subQuestion.ans:
Let △ABC and △PQR be two right triangles with AD ⊥ BC and PS ⊥ QR.
BC = 9, AD = 5, PS = 6 and QR = 10.
The ratio of areas of two triangles is equal to the ratio of the products of their bases and corresponding heights.
A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = (AD × BC)/(PS × QR)
∴ A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = (5 × 9)/(6 × 10)
∴ A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = 3/4
Hence, Ratio of Area of △ABC : Area of △PQR = 3 : 4.

questions.questionsTitle: In adjoining figure, seg PS ⊥ seg RQ, seg QT ⊥ seg PR. If RQ = 6, PS = 6 and PR = 12, then Find QT.

subQuestion.question: In adjoining figure, seg PS ⊥ seg RQ, seg QT ⊥ seg PR. If RQ = 6, PS = 6 and PR = 12, then Find QT.
subQuestion.ans:
seg PS ⊥ seg RQ
seg QT ⊥ seg PR
RQ = 6, PS = 6 and PR = 12   ...(Given)
With base PR and height QT,
A(△PQR) = 1/2 × PR × QT   ...(1)
With base QR and height PS,
A(△PQR) = 1/2 × QR × PS   ...(2)
The ratio of areas of two triangles is equal to the ratio of the product of their base and corresponding heights.
From (1) and (2),
A(△PQR)/A(△PQR) = (1/2 × PR × QT)/(1/2 × QR × PS)
1/1 = (PR × QT)/(QR × PS)
PR × QT = QR × PS
QT = (QR × PS)/PR
QT = (6 × 6)/12
QT = 3/1
Hence, the measure of side QT is 3 units.

questions.questionsTitle: Given below is the triangle and length of line segments. Identify in the given figure, ray PM is the bisector of ∠QPR.

subQuestion.question: Given below is the triangle and length of line segments. Identify in the given figure, ray PM is the bisector of ∠QPR.
subQuestion.ans:
In △PQR,
PQ = 7, PR = 3, QM = 3.5, and MR = 1.5 ...(Given)
PQ/PR = 7/3 ...(i)
QM/MR = 3.5/1.5 = (3.5 × 10)/(1.5 × 10) = 35/15 = 7/3 ...(ii)
From (i) and (ii)
∴ PQ/PR = QM/MR
∴ by converse of angle bisector theorem,
∴ Ray PM is the bisector of ∠QPR.

questions.questionsTitle: Given below is the triangle and length of line segments. Identify in the given figure, ray PM is the bisector of ∠QPR.

subQuestion.question: Given below is the triangle and length of line segments. Identify in the given figure, ray PM is the bisector of ∠QPR.

RM/QM = 4/3.6 = (4×10)/(3.6×10) = 40/36 = 10/9 ...(2)
From Equation (1) & (2)
∴ PR/PQ = RM/QM
By converse of angle bisector theorem, ray PM is the bisector of ∠QPR.

questions.questionsTitle: In △PQR, PM = 15, PQ = 25 PR = 20, NR = 8. State whether line NM is parallel to side RQ. Give reason.

subQuestion.question: In △PQR, PM = 15, PQ = 25 PR = 20, NR = 8. State whether line NM is parallel to side RQ. Give reason.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
PM = 15, PQ = 25, PR = 20 and NR = 8
PQ = PM + MQ
25 = 15 + MQ
⇒ MQ = 25 - 15 = 10
⇒ MQ = 10
PR = PN + NR
20 = PN + 8
⇒ PN = 20 - 8
⇒ PN = 12
PM/MQ = 15/10 = 3/2
PN/NR = 12/8 = 3/2
In △PQR,
PM/MQ = PN/NR
By converse of basic proportionality theorem, NM is parallel to side RQ or NM || RQ.

Proof:

∴ ∠APQ ≅ ∠ABC
∴ Seg PQ || Seg BC        ...(Corresponding angles test for parallel lines)(I)
In △ABC,
Seg PQ || Seg BC          ...[From I]
By Basic proportionality theorem,
∴ AP/PB = AQ/QC
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: In trapezium ABCD, side AB || side PQ || side DC, AP = 15, PD = 12, QC = 14, Find BQ.

subQuestion.question: In trapezium ABCD, side AB || side PQ || side DC, AP = 15, PD = 12, QC = 14, Find BQ.
subQuestion.ans:
side AB || side PQ || side DC          ...(Given)
∴ By the Property of three parallel lines and their transversals,
AP/PD = BQ/QC
∴ 15/12 = BQ/14
∴ 15 × 14 = 12 × BQ
∴ BQ = (15 × 14)/12
∴ BQ = (5 × 7)/2
∴ BQ = 35/2
∴ BQ = 17.5 units

questions.questionsTitle: In △ABC, ray BD bisects ∠ABC and ray CE bisects ∠ACB. If seg AB ≅ seg AC then prove that ED || BC.

subQuestion.question: In △ABC, ray BD bisects ∠ABC and ray CE bisects  angleACB. If seg AB ≅ seg AC then prove that ED || BC.
subQuestion.ans:
In △ABC, ray BD is the bisector of ∠ABC
∴ by the theorem of an angle bisector of a triangle,
AB/BC = AD/DC      ...(1)
In △ABC, ray CE is the bisector of ∠ACB
∴ by the theorem of an angle bisector of a triangle,
AC/BC = AE/EB       ...(2)
Seg AB ≅ seg AC (Given)   ...(3)
[From (1), (2) and (3)]
∴ AB/BC = AC/BC   ...(4)
In △ABC,
AE/EB = AD/DC   ...[From (1), (2) and (4)]
∴ by converse of basic proportionality theorem,
seg ED || side BC
∴ ED || BC

questions.questionsTitle: In △ABC, AP ⊥ BC, BQ ⊥ AC B–P–C, A–Q–C then prove that, △CPA ~ △CQB. If AP = 7, BQ = 8, BC = 12 then Find AC.

subQuestion.question: In △ABC, AP ⊥ BC, BQ ⊥ AC B–P–C, A–Q–C then prove that, △CPA ~ △CQB. If AP = 7, BQ = 8, BC = 12 then Find AC.
subQuestion.ans:
In △CPA and △CQB,
∠CPA ≅ ∠CQB [Each angle is of measure 90°]
∠ACP ≅ ∠BCQ [Common angle]
∴ △CPA ~ △CQB [AA test of similarity]
∴ AC/BC = AP/BQ   [Corresponding sides of similar triangle]
∴ AC/12 = 7/8
∴ AC = (12 × 7)/8
∴ AC = 10.5 units.

questions.questionsTitle: In trapezium PQRS, side PQ || side SR, AR = 5AP, AS = 5AQ then prove that, SR = 5PQ

subQuestion.question: In trapezium PQRS, side PQ || side SR, AR = 5AP, AS = 5AQ then prove that, SR = 5PQ
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
side PQ || side SR
AR = 5AP,
AS = 5AQ
To prove: SR = 5PQ
Proof: In △APQ and △ARS
∠PAQ = ∠RAS          (Vertically Opposite angles)
∠PQA = ∠RSA          (Alternate angles, side PQ || side SR and QS is a transversal line)
By AA test of similarity
△APQ ~ △ARS
PQ/SR = AP/AR (Corresponding sides are proportional)
⇒ PQ/SR = 1/5 (AR = 5AP)
⇒ SR = 5PQ
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: In trapezium ABCD, side AB || side DC, diagonals AC and BD intersect in point O. If AB = 20, DC = 6, OB = 15 then Find OD.

subQuestion.question: In trapezium ABCD, side AB || side DC, diagonals AC and BD intersect in point O. If AB = 20, DC = 6, OB = 15 then Find OD.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
side AB || side DC
AB = 20,
DC = 6,
OB = 15
In △COD and △AOB
∠COD = ∠AOB         (Vertically opposite angles)
∠CDO = ∠ABO         (Alternate angles, CD || BA and BD is a transversal line)
By AA test of similarity
△COD ∼ △AOB
∴ CD/AB = OD/OB (Corresponding sides are proportional)
⇒ 6/20 = OD/15
⇒ OD = 4.

questions.questionsTitle: ◻ABCD is a parallelogram point E is on side BC. Line DE intersects ray AB in point T. Prove that DE × BE = CE × TE.

subQuestion.question: ◻ABCD is a parallelogram point E is on side BC. Line DE intersects ray AB in point T. Prove that DE × BE = CE × TE.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
◻ABCD is a parallelogram.
E is a point on side BC.
Line DE intersects ray AB in point T.
To prove:
DE × BE = CE × TE
Proof:
In △BET and △CED
∠BET = ∠CED   ...(Vertically opposite angles)
∠BTE = ∠CDE   ...(Alternate interior angles, AB || CD and DT is a transversal line)
By AA test of similarity,
△BET ∼ △CED
∴ BE/CE = ET/ED
∴ DE × BE = CE × TE

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, in △ABC, point D on side BC is such that, ∠BAC = ∠ADC. Prove that, CA^2 = CB × CD.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, in △ABC, point D on side BC is such that, ∠BAC = ∠ADC. Prove that, CA^2 = CB × CD.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
In △BAC and △ADC,
∠BAC ≅ ∠ADC    ...(Given)
∠ACB ≅ ∠DCA    ...(Common angle)
∴ △BAC ∼ △ADC    ...(AA test of similarity)
∴ CA/CD = CB/CA    ...(Corresponding sides of similar triangles are in proportion)
∴ CA^2 = CB × CD.

questions.questionsTitle: The ratio of corresponding sides of similar triangles is 3 : 5; then find the ratio of their areas.

subQuestion.question: The ratio of corresponding sides of similar triangles is 3 : 5; then find the ratio of their areas.
subQuestion.ans:
Let the ratio of corresponding sides of similar triangles be S1 and S2 and A1 and A2 be their corresponding areas.
Given:
The two triangles are similar.
S1 : S2 = 3 : 5
∴ S1/S2 = 3/5   ...(i)
By Theorem of areas of similar triangles,
A1/A2 = (S1)^2/(S2)^2
A1/A2 = (S1/S2)^2
A1/A2 = (3/5)^2   ...[From (i)]
A1/A2 = 9/25
∴ The ratio of areas of similar triangles = 9 : 25.

questions.questionsTitle: If △ABC ~ △PQR and AB : PQ = 2 : 3, then fill in the blanks. A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = AB^2/... = 2^2/3^2 = .../...

subQuestion.question: If △ABC ~ △PQR and AB : PQ = 2 : 3, then fill in the blanks.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
△ABC ~ △PQR
AB : PQ = 2 : 3
According to theorem of areas of similar triangles "When two triangles are similar, the ratio of areas of those triangles is equal to the ratio of the squares of their corresponding sides".
∴ A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = AB^2/PQ^2 = 2^2/3^2 = 4/9

questions.questionsTitle: If △ABC ~ △PQR, A(△ABC) = 80, A(△PQR) = 125, then fill in the blanks. A(△ABC)/A(△...) = 80/125 ∴ AB/PQ = .../...

subQuestion.question: If △ABC ~ △PQR, A(△ABC) = 80, A(△PQR) = 125, then fill in the blanks. A(△ABC)/A(△...) = 80/125 ∴ AB/PQ = .../...
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
△ABC ~ △PQR
A(△ABC) = 80
A(△PQR) = 125
According to theorem of areas of similar triangles "When two triangles are similar, the ratio of areas of those triangles is equal to the ratio of the squares of their corresponding sides".
∴ A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = AB^2/PQ^2
⇒ 80/125 = AB^2/PQ^2
⇒ 16/25 = AB^2/PQ^2
⇒ 4^2/5^2 = AB^2/PQ^2
⇒ AB/PQ = 4/5
Therefore,
A(△ABC)/A(△PQR) = 80/125 and AB/PQ = 4/5

questions.questionsTitle: △LMN ~ △PQR, 9 × A(△PQR) = 16 × A(△LMN). If QR = 20 then Find MN.

subQuestion.question: △LMN ~ △PQR, 9 × A(△PQR) = 16 × A(△LMN). If QR = 20 then Find MN.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
QR = 20
△LMN ~ △PQR
9 × A(△PQR) = 16 × A(△LMN)
Consider, 9 × A(△PQR) = 16 × A(△LMN)
A(△LMN)/A(△PQR) = 9/16
⇒ MN^2/QR^2 = 3^2/4^2
⇒ MN/QR = 3/4
⇒ MN = 3/4 × QR
⇒ MN = 3/4 × 20 [∵ QR = 20]
⇒ MN = 15

questions.questionsTitle: Areas of two similar triangles are 225 sq.cm. 81 sq.cm. If a side of the smaller triangle is 12 cm, then Find corresponding side of the bigger triangle.

subQuestion.question: Areas of two similar triangles are 225 sq.cm. 81 sq.cm. If a side of the smaller triangle is 12 cm, then Find corresponding side of the bigger triangle.
subQuestion.ans:
Let areas of two similar triangles be A1 and A2 & their corresponding sides be S1 and S2
A1 = 225 sq.cm, A2 = 81 sq.cm
S2 = 12 cm, S1 = ?
A1/A2 = S1^2/S2^2   ...[Theorem of areas of similar triangle]
225/81 = S1^2/(12)^2
Taking square root on both side
√(225/81) = √(S1/12)
15/9 = S1/12
15/9 × 12 = S1
∴ S1 = 20 cm

questions.questionsTitle: △ABC and △DEF are equilateral triangles. If A(△ABC) : A(△DEF) = 1 : 2 and AB = 4, find DE.

subQuestion.question: △ABC and △DEF are equilateral triangles. If A(△ABC) : A(△DEF) = 1 : 2 and AB = 4, find DE.
subQuestion.ans:
In △ABC and △DEF,
∠A ≅ ∠D,
∠B ≅ ∠E   ...(Each angle is of measure 60°)
∴ △ABC ∼ △DEF   ...(AA test of similarity)
By the Theorem of areas of similar triangles,
∴ A(△ABC)/A(△DEF) = AB^2/DE^2
∴ 1/2 = 4^2/DE^2
∴ DE^2 = 4^2 × 2
Taking square root of both sides,
∴ DE = 4√2 units

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure 1.66, seg PQ || seg DE, A(△PQF) = 20 units, PF = 2 DP, then Find A(◻DPQE) by completing the following activity.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure 1.66, seg PQ || seg DE, A(△PQF) = 20 units, PF = 2 DP, then Find A(◻DPQE) by completing the following activity.
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
seg PQ || seg DE
A(△PQF) = 20 units
PF = 2 DP
Let us assume DP = x
∴ PF = 2x
DF = DP + PF = x + 2x = 3x
In △FDE and △FPQ
∠FDE = ∠FPQ         (Corresponding angles)
∠FED = ∠FQP         (Corresponding angles)
By AA test of similarity
△FDE ∼ △FPQ
∴ A(△FDE)/A(△FPQ) = FD^2/FP^2 = (3x)^2/(2x)^2 = 9/4
A(△FDE) = 9/4 A(△FPQ) = 9/4 × 20 = 45
∴ A(◻DPQE) = A(△FDE) - A(△FPQ)
= 45 - 20
= 25

subQuestion.question: If in △DEF and △PQR, ∠D ≅ ∠Q, ∠R ≅ ∠E then which of the following statements is false?
subQuestion.ans:
DE/PQ = EF/RP
Explanation:

∠D ≅ ∠Q
∠E ≅ ∠R

△DEF ~ △PQR

questions.questionsTitle: In △ABC and △DEF ∠B = ∠E, ∠F = ∠C and AB = 3DE then which of the statements regarding the two triangles is true ?

subQuestion.question: In △ABC and △DEF ∠B = ∠E, ∠F = ∠C and AB = 3DE then which of the statements regarding the two triangles is true ?
subQuestion.ans:
In △ABC and △DEF
∠B = ∠E,
∠F = ∠C
By AA test of similarity
△ABC ~ △DEF
Since, there is not any congruency criteria like AA.
Thus, △ABC and △DEF are not congruent.
Hence, the correct option is The triangles are similar but not congruent.

questions.questionsTitle: △ABC and △DEF are equilateral triangles, A(△ABC): A(△DEF) = 1: 2. If AB = 4 then what is length of DE?

subQuestion.question: △ABC and △DEF are equilateral triangles, A(△ABC): A(△DEF) = 1: 2. If AB = 4 then what is length of DE?
subQuestion.ans: △ABC and △DEF are equilateral triangles.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, seg XY || seg BC, then which of the following statements is true?

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, seg XY || seg BC, then which of the following statements is true?
subQuestion.ans:
Given:
seg XY || seg BC
AX/BX = AY/YC    .......(By basic proportionality theorem)
⇒ (BX/AX) + 1 = (YC/AY) + 1
⇒ (BX + AX)/AX = (YC + AY)/AY
⇒ AB/AX = AC/AY
⇒ AB/AC = AX/AY
Hence, the correct option is AB/AC = AX/AY

questions.questionsTitle: In △ABC, B - D - C and BD = 7, BC = 20 then find following ratio. A(△ABD)/A(△ADC)

subQuestion.question: In △ABC, B - D - C and BD = 7, BC = 20 then find following ratio. A(△ABD)/A(△ADC)
subQuestion.ans:
In △ABC,
B - D - C, BD = 7, BC = 20
DC = BC - BD = 20 - 7 = 13
In △ABD and △ADC, both triangles have the same height.
Areas of triangles with equal heights are proportional to their bases.
∴ A(△ABD)/A(△ADC) = BD/DC
= 7/13

questions.questionsTitle: If 5 secθ – 12 cosecθ = 0, find the values of secθ, cosθ, and sinθ.

subQuestion.question: If 5 secθ – 12 cosecθ = 0, find the values of secθ, cosθ, and sinθ.
subQuestion.ans:
5 secθ - 12 cosecθ = 0
⇒ 5 secθ = 12 cosecθ
⇒ 5 × 1/cosθ = 12 × 1/sinθ
⇒ 5/cosθ = 12/sinθ
⇒ sinθ/cosθ = 12/5
⇒ tanθ = 12/5    ...[tanθ = sinθ/cosθ]
We have,
sec^2θ = 1 + tan^2θ
⇒ sec^2θ = 1 + (12/5)^2
⇒ sec^2θ = 1 + 144/25
⇒ sec^2θ = 169/25
Taking square root on both sides,
√(sec^2θ) = √(169/25)
∴ secθ = 13/5
Now,
cosθ = 1/secθ
⇒ cosθ = 1/(13/5)
⇒ cosθ = 5/13
Also,
sinθ/cosθ = tanθ
⇒ sinθ = tanθ × cosθ
⇒ sinθ = 12/5 × 5/13 = 12/13
Thus, the values of secθ, cosθ and sinθ are 13/5, 5/13 and 12/13 respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: If tanθ = 1 then, find the value of (sinθ + cosθ)/(secθ + cosecθ)

subQuestion.question: If tanθ = 1 then, find the value of
subQuestion.ans:
tanθ = 1      ...(Given)
We know that, tan 45° = 1
∴ θ = 45º
Now,
sinθ = sin 45º = 1/√2
cosθ = cos 45º = 1/√2
secθ = sec 45º = √2
cosecθ = cosec 45º = √2
∴ (sinθ + cosθ)/(secθ + cosecθ)
⇒ (1/√2 + 1/√2)/(√2 + √2)
⇒ (2/√2)/(2√2)
⇒ 2/√2 × 1/(2√2)
⇒ 1/2
∴ (sinθ + cosθ)/(secθ + cosecθ) = 1/2

subQuestion.question: (sinθ + cosθ)/(secθ + cosecθ)
subQuestion.ans: No solution available

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that:

subQuestion.question: (sin^2θ)/(cosθ) + cosθ = secθ
subQuestion.ans:
LHS = (sin^2θ)/(cosθ) + cosθ = secθ
= (sin^2θ + cos^2θ)/(cosθ)
= 1/(cosθ)   ...(sin^2θ + cos^2θ = 1)
= secθ   ...(1/cosθ = secθ)
R.H.S
LHS = RHS
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: cos^2θ (1 + tan^2θ)

subQuestion.question: Prove that:
subQuestion.ans: L.H.S.

subQuestion.question: cos^2θ (1 + tan^2θ)
subQuestion.ans:
= cos^2θ (1 + tan^2θ)
= cos^2θ × sec^2θ          ...[∵ 1 + tan^2θ = sec^2θ]
= cos^2θ × 1/cos^2θ
= 1
= R.H.S.
∴ cos^2θ (1 + tan^2θ) = 1

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: √((1 - sinθ)/(1 + sinθ)) = secθ - tanθ

subQuestion.question: Prove that:
subQuestion.ans:
√((1 - sinθ)/(1 + sinθ))
= √((1 - sinθ)/(1 + sinθ) × (1 - sinθ)/(1 - sinθ))
= √((1 - sinθ)^2/(1 - sin^2θ))
= √((1 - sinθ)^2/(cos^2θ)) (cos^2θ + sin^2θ = 1)
= (1 - sinθ)/(cosθ)
= 1/cosθ - sinθ/cosθ
= secθ - tanθ

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: (secθ - cosθ)(cotθ + tanθ) = tanθ secθ.

subQuestion.question: (secθ - cosθ)(cotθ + tanθ) = tanθ secθ.
subQuestion.ans:
(secθ - cosθ)(cotθ + tanθ) = tanθ secθ.
LHS = (secθ - cosθ)(cotθ + tanθ)
LHS = (1/cosθ - cosθ)(cosθ/sinθ + sinθ/cosθ)   ...{(secθ = 1/cosθ),(cotθ = cosθ/sinθ),(tanθ = sinθ/cosθ)}
LHS = ((1 - cos^2θ)/cosθ)((cos^2θ + sin^2θ)/(sinθ cosθ))
LHS = ((sin^2θ)/cosθ) × (1/(sinθ cosθ))   ...{(cos^2θ + sin^2θ = 1),(∵ 1 - cos^2θ = sin^2θ)}
LHS = ((sin^2θ)/cosθ) × (1/(sinθ cosθ))
LHS = sinθ/cosθ × 1/cosθ
LHS = tanθ secθ   ...{(sinθ/cosθ = tanθ),(1/cosθ = secθ)}
RHS = tanθ secθ
LHS = RHS
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: cotθ + tanθ = cosecθ secθ

subQuestion.question: Prove that:
subQuestion.ans:
cotθ + tanθ
= cosθ/sinθ + sinθ/cosθ
= (sin^2θ + cos^2θ)/(sinθ cosθ)
= 1/(sinθ cosθ) (sin^2θ + cos^2θ = 1)
= 1/sinθ × 1/cosθ
= cosecθ secθ

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: 1/(secθ − tanθ) = secθ + tanθ

subQuestion.question: Prove that: 1/(secθ − tanθ) = secθ + tanθ
subQuestion.ans:
LHS = 1/(secθ − tanθ)
LHS = 1/(secθ − tanθ) × (secθ + tanθ)/(secθ + tanθ)
LHS = (secθ + tanθ)/((secθ − tanθ)(secθ + tanθ))
LHS = (secθ + tanθ)/(sec^2θ − tan^2θ)   ...[(a + b)(a - b) = a^2 - b^2]
LHS = (secθ + tanθ)/1                      ...{(1 + tan^2θ = sec^2θ),(∴ sec^2θ − tan^2θ = 1)}
LHS = secθ + tanθ
RHS = secθ + tanθ
LHS = RHS
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: sin^4θ - cos^4θ = 1 - 2cos^2θ

subQuestion.question: Prove that: sin^4θ – cos^4θ = 1 – 2cos^2θ
subQuestion.ans:
sin^4θ – cos^4θ = 1 – 2cos^2θ
LHS = sin^4θ – cos^4θ
LHS = (sin^2θ)^2 – (cos^2θ)^2
LHS = (sin^2θ + cos^2θ)(sin^2θ - cos^2θ)       ...[a^2 – b^2 = (a + b)(a – b)]
LHS = (sin^2θ – cos^2θ)(1)         ...(sin^2θ + cos^2θ = 1)
LHS = 1 – cos^2θ – cos^2θ          ...(1 – sin^2θ = cos^2θ)
LHS = 1 – 2cos^2θ
RHS = 1 – 2cos^2θ
LHS = RHS
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: secθ + tanθ = cosθ/(1 - sinθ)

subQuestion.question: Prove that: secθ + tanθ = cosθ/(1 - sinθ)
subQuestion.ans:
L.H.S.
secθ + tanθ
= 1/cosθ + sinθ/cosθ
= (1 + sinθ)/cosθ
= (1 + sinθ)/(cosθ) × (1 - sinθ)/(1 - sinθ)
= (1 - sin^2θ)/(cosθ (1 - sinθ))
= cos^2θ/(cosθ (1 - sinθ)) (sin^2θ + cos^2θ = 1)
= cosθ/(1 - sinθ)
= R.H.S.
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: If tanθ + 1/tanθ = 2, then show that tan^2θ + 1/tan^2θ = 2

subQuestion.question: Prove that: If tanθ + 1/tanθ = 2, then show that tan^2θ + 1/tan^2θ = 2
subQuestion.ans:
tanθ + 1/tanθ = 2
Squaring on both sides, we get
(tanθ + 1/tanθ)^2 = 2^2
⇒ tan^2θ + 1/tan^2θ + 2 × tanθ × 1/tanθ = 4
⇒ tan^2θ + 1/tan^2θ + 2 = 4
⇒ tan^2θ + 1/tan^2θ = 2
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: tanA/(1 + tan^2A)^2 + cotA/(1 + cot^2A)^2 = sinA cosA

subQuestion.question: Prove that: tanA/(1 + tan^2A)^2 + cotA/(1 + cot^2A)^2 = sinA cosA
subQuestion.ans:
tanA/(1 + tan^2A)^2 + cotA/(1 + cot^2A)^2 = sinA cosA.
LHS = tanA/(1 + tan^2A)^2 + cotA/(1 + cot^2A)^2
LHS = tanA/(sec^2A)^2 + cotA/(cosec^2A)^2        ...{(1 + tan^2θ = sec^2θ),(1 + cot^2θ = cosec^2θ)}
LHS = tanA × 1/(sec^2A)^2 + cotA × 1/(cosec^2A)^2
LHS = sinA/cosA × cos^4A + cosA/sinA × sin^4A   ...{(cosθ = 1/secθ),(sinθ = 1/cosecθ)}
LHS = sinA cos^3A + cosA sin^3A
LHS = sinA cosA (cos^2A + sin^2A)
LHS = sinA cosA (1)               ...(cos^2A + sin^2A = 1)
LHS = sinA cosA
RHS = sinA cosA
LHS = RHS
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: sec^4A (1 - sin^4A) - 2 tan^2A

subQuestion.question: Prove that: sec^4A (1 - sin^4A) - 2 tan^2A
subQuestion.ans:
L.H.S = sec^4A (1 - sin^4A) - 2 tan^2A
= sec^4A - sec^4A sin^4A - 2 tan^2A
= sec^4A - (1/cos^4A) × sin^4A - 2 tan^2A
= sec^4A - (sin^4A/cos^4A) - 2 tan^2A
= sec^4A - tan^4A - 2 tan^2A
= (sec^2A - tan^2A)(sec^2A + tan^2A) - 2 tan^2A
= (1)(sec^2A + tan^2A) - 2 tan^2A   ...[∵ sec^2A - tan^2A = 1]
= sec^2A + tan^2A - 2 tan^2A
= sec^2A - tan^2A
= 1
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that: tanθ/(secθ – 1) = (tanθ + secθ + 1)/(tanθ + secθ - 1)

subQuestion.question: Prove that: tanθ/(secθ – 1) = (tanθ + secθ + 1)/(tanθ + secθ - 1)
subQuestion.ans:
tanθ/(secθ – 1) = (tanθ + secθ + 1)/(tanθ + secθ - 1)
RHS = (tanθ + secθ + 1)/(tanθ + secθ - 1)
RHS = (tanθ + secθ + 1)/((tanθ + secθ) - 1) × (tanθ + secθ + 1)/((tanθ + secθ) + 1)         ...(On rationalising the denominator)
RHS = ((tanθ + secθ + 1)^2)/((tanθ + secθ)^2 - 1)
RHS = (tan^2θ + sec^2θ + 1 + 2tanθ secθ + 2tanθ + 2secθ)/(tan^2θ + 2tanθ secθ + sec^2θ - 1) ...{((a + b + c)^2 = a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + 2ab + 2ac + 2bc),((a + b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2)}
RHS = ((1 + tan^2θ) + sec^2θ + 2tanθ secθ + 2tanθ + 2secθ)/(tan^2θ + 2tanθ secθ + (sec^2θ - 1))
RHS = (sec^2θ + sec^2θ + 2tanθ secθ + 2tanθ + 2secθ)/(tan^2θ + 2tanθ secθ + tan^2θ)
RHS = (2sec^2θ + 2tanθ secθ + 2tanθ + 2secθ)/(2tan^2θ + 2tanθ secθ)
RHS = [2secθ (tanθ + secθ) + 2(tanθ + secθ)]/[2tanθ(tanθ + secθ)]
RHS = [(2secθ + 2)(tanθ + secθ)]/[2tanθ(tanθ + secθ)]
RHS = [2(secθ + 1)]/[2tanθ]
RHS = (secθ + 1)/(tanθ)
RHS = (secθ + 1)/(tanθ) × (secθ - 1)/(secθ - 1)
RHS = (sec^2θ - 1)/(tanθ(secθ - 1))        ...[(a - b)(a + b) = a^2 - b^2]
RHS = (tan^2θ)/(tanθ(secθ - 1))
RHS = tanθ/(secθ - 1)
LHS = tanθ/(secθ – 1)
LHS = RHS
Hence proved.

questions.questionsTitle: A person is standing at a distance of 80 m from a church looking at its top. The angle of elevation is of 45°. Find the height of the church.

subQuestion.question: A person is standing at a distance of 80 m from a church looking at its top. The angle of elevation is of 45°. Find the height of the church.
subQuestion.ans:
Let AB be the church and C be the position of the person from the church.
Suppose the height of the church be h m.
In right △ABC,
tan 45° = AB/BC
⇒ 1 = h/80
⇒ h = 80 m
Thus, the height of the church is 80 m.

questions.questionsTitle: From the top of a lighthouse, an observer looking at a ship makes angle of depression of 60°. If the height of the lighthouse is 90 metre, then find how far the ship is from the lighthouse. (√3 = 1.73)

subQuestion.question: From the top of a lighthouse, an observer looking at a ship makes angle of depression of 60°. If the height of the lighthouse is 90 metre, then find how far the ship is from the lighthouse.
subQuestion.ans:
Let AB be the lighthouse and C be the position of the ship from the lighthouse.
Suppose the distance of the ship from the lighthouse be x m.
In right △ABC,
tan 60° = AB/BC
⇒ √3 = 90/x
⇒ x = 90/√3 = 30√3
⇒ x = 30 × 1.73
⇒ x = 51.9 m
Thus, the ship is 51.9 m away from the lighthouse.

questions.questionsTitle: Two buildings are facing each other on a road of width 12 metre. From the top of the first building, which is 10 metre high, the angle of elevation of the top of the second is found to be 60°. What is the height of the second building?

subQuestion.question: Two buildings are facing each other on a road of width 12 metre. From the top of the first building, which is 10 metre high, the angle of elevation of the top of the second is found to be 60°. What is the height of the second building?
subQuestion.ans:
Let AB and CD be two buildings, with
AB = 10 m
And angle of elevation from top of AB to top of CD = ∠CAP = 60°
Width of road = BD = 12 m
Clearly, ABDP is a rectangle
With
AB = PD = 10 m
BD = AP = 12 m
And APC is a right-angled triangle, In △APC
tanθ = Perpendicular/Base = CP/AP
⇒ tan 60° = CP/12
⇒ √3 = CP/12
⇒ CP = 12√3 m
Also,
CD = CP + PD = (12√3 + 10) m
Hence, height of other building is (10 + 12√3 m).

questions.questionsTitle: Two poles of heights 18 metre and 7 metre are erected on a ground. The length of the wire fastened at their tops is 22 metre. Find the angle made by the wire with the horizontal.

subQuestion.question: Two poles of heights 18 metre and 7 metre are erected on a ground. The length of the wire fastened at their tops is 22 metre. Find the angle made by the wire with the horizontal.
subQuestion.ans:
Let AB and CD be the two poles standing on the ground.
Suppose the angle made by the wire with the horizontal be θ.
Here, AB = 18 m and CD = 7 m.
Length of the wire fastened at their tops = AC = 22 m
AE = AB − EB = 18 − 7 = 11 m            (EB = CD)
In right △AEC,
sinθ = AE/AC
⇒ sinθ = 11/22 = 1/2
⇒ sinθ = 1/2 = sin 30°
⇒ θ = 30°
Thus, the angle made by the wire with the horizontal is 30º.

questions.questionsTitle: A storm broke a tree and the treetop rested 20 m from the base of the tree, making an angle of 60° with the horizontal. Find the height of the tree.

subQuestion.question: A storm broke a tree and the treetop rested 20 m from the base of the tree, making an angle of 60° with the horizontal. Find the height of the tree.
subQuestion.ans:
Let AC be the original height of the tree.
Suppose the height of the tree be h m.
After the storm, the treetop rests at point B, such that BC = 20 m and ∠ABC = 60°.
In right △ABC,
tan 60° = AC/BC
⇒ √3 = h/20
⇒ h = 20√3 m
Also,
sin 60° = AC/AB
⇒ √3/2 = 20√3/AB
⇒ AB = 40 m
Thus, the height of the tree is 20√3 m and the length of the broken part is 40 m.
Total height of the tree = AC + CB (assuming CB is vertical for simplicity)
However, since CB is the broken part resting at 60°, we use only AC for height.
Hence, height of the tree = 20√3 m.

questions.questionsTitle: A kite is flying at a height of 60 m above the ground. The string attached to the kite is tied at the ground. It makes an angle of 60° with the ground. Assuming that the string is straight, find the length of the string. (√3 = 1.73)

subQuestion.questionsTitle: A kite is flying at a height of 60 m above the ground. The string attached to the kite is tied at the ground. It makes an angle of 60° with the ground. Assuming that the string is straight, find the length of the string.\[\left( \sqrt{3} = 1.73 \right)\]

subQuestion.question: A kite is flying at a height of 60 m above the ground. The string attached to the kite is tied at the ground. It makes an angle of 60° with the ground. Assuming that the string is straight, find the length of the string.
subQuestion.ans: Let AB be the height of the kite above the ground and C be the point where the string is tied to the ground. Suppose the length of the string is x meters. Here, AB = 60 m and ∠ACB = 60°. In right triangle ABC, \[\sin 60^\circ = \frac{AB}{AC}\] \[ \Rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{60}{x}\] \[ \Rightarrow x = \frac{60 \times 2}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{120}{\sqrt{3}} = 40\sqrt{3}\] \[ \Rightarrow x = 40 \times 1.73 = 69.2 \text{ m}\] Thus, the length of the string is approximately 69.2 meters.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. \[\sin \theta \cosec \theta = ?\]

subQuestion.question: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. \[\sin \theta \cosec \theta = ?\]
subQuestion.ans: \[\sin \theta \cosec \theta = \sin \theta \times \frac{1}{\sin \theta} = 1\] Hence, the correct answer is 1.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. \[\cosec 45^\circ = ?\]

subQuestion.question: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. \[\cosec 45^\circ = ?\]
subQuestion.ans: \[\cosec 45^\circ = \frac{1}{\sin 45^\circ} = \frac{1}{\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}} = \sqrt{2}\] Hence, the correct answer is \[\sqrt{2}\].

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = ?\]

subQuestion.question: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = ?\]
subQuestion.ans: \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta\] Hence, the correct answer is \[\sec^2 \theta\].

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. When we see at a higher level, from the horizontal line, angle formed is ........

subQuestion.question: Choose the correct alternative answer for the following question. When we see at a higher level, from the horizontal line, angle formed is ........
subQuestion.ans: When we see at a higher level from the horizontal line, the angle formed is the angle of elevation. Hence, the correct answer is angle of elevation.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: If \[\sin \theta = \frac{11}{61}\], find the values of \[\cos \theta\] using trigonometric identity.

subQuestion.question: If \[\sin \theta = \frac{11}{61}\], find the values of \[\cos \theta\] using trigonometric identity.
subQuestion.ans: \[\sin \theta = \frac{11}{61}\] (Given). Using the trigonometric identity \[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\], \[\cos^2 \theta = 1 - \sin^2 \theta\] \[\Rightarrow \cos^2 \theta = 1 - \left(\frac{11}{61}\right)^2 = 1 - \frac{121}{3721} = \frac{3721 - 121}{3721} = \frac{3600}{3721}\] \[\Rightarrow \cos \theta = \sqrt{\frac{3600}{3721}} = \frac{60}{61}\] (since \[\cos \theta\] is positive). Thus, the value of \[\cos \theta\] is \[\frac{60}{61}\].

subQuestion.questionsTitle: If \[\tan \theta = 2\], find the values of other trigonometric ratios.

subQuestion.question: If \[\tan \theta = 2\], find the values of other trigonometric ratios.
subQuestion.ans: \[\tan \theta = 2\] (Given). Therefore, \[\cot \theta = \frac{1}{\tan \theta} = \frac{1}{2}\]. Using the identity \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta\], \[\sec^2 \theta = 1 + (2)^2 = 1 + 4 = 5\] \[\Rightarrow \sec \theta = \sqrt{5}\] (positive). Then, \[\cos \theta = \frac{1}{\sec \theta} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\]. Since \[\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\], \[\sin \theta = \tan \theta \cdot \cos \theta = 2 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{5}}{5} = \frac{2 \sqrt{5}}{5}\]. Thus, \[\csc \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta} = \frac{1}{\frac{2 \sqrt{5}}{5}} = \frac{5}{2 \sqrt{5}} = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{2}\]. Therefore, the trigonometric ratios are: \[\sin \theta = \frac{2 \sqrt{5}}{5}\], \[\cos \theta = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\], \[\csc \theta = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{2}\], \[\sec \theta = \sqrt{5}\], \[\cot \theta = \frac{1}{2}\].

subQuestion.questionsTitle: If \[\sec \theta = \frac{13}{12}\], find the values of other trigonometric ratios.

subQuestion.question: If \[\sec \theta = \frac{13}{12}\], find the values of other trigonometric ratios.
subQuestion.ans: \[\sec \theta = \frac{13}{12}\] (Given). Therefore, \[\cos \theta = \frac{1}{\sec \theta} = \frac{12}{13}\]. Using the identity \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta\], \[\tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta - 1 = \left(\frac{13}{12}\right)^2 - 1 = \frac{169}{144} - 1 = \frac{25}{144}\] \[\Rightarrow \tan \theta = \frac{5}{12}\] (positive). Then, \[\cot \theta = \frac{1}{\tan \theta} = \frac{12}{5}\]. Since \[\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\], \[\sin \theta = \tan \theta \cdot \cos \theta = \frac{5}{12} \cdot \frac{12}{13} = \frac{5}{13}\]. Thus, \[\csc \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta} = \frac{13}{5}\]. Therefore, the trigonometric ratios are: \[\sin \theta = \frac{5}{13}\], \[\cos \theta = \frac{12}{13}\], \[\tan \theta = \frac{5}{12}\], \[\csc \theta = \frac{13}{5}\], \[\cot \theta = \frac{12}{5}\].

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\sec \theta (1 - \sin \theta)(\sec \theta + \tan \theta) = 1\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\sec \theta (1 - \sin \theta)(\sec \theta + \tan \theta) = 1\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\sec \theta (1 - \sin \theta)(\sec \theta + \tan \theta)\] = \[\frac{1}{\cos \theta} (1 - \sin \theta) \left( \frac{1}{\cos \theta} + \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} \right)\] = \[\frac{1 - \sin \theta}{\cos \theta} \cdot \frac{1 + \sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{(1 - \sin \theta)(1 + \sin \theta)}{\cos^2 \theta}\] = \[\frac{1 - \sin^2 \theta}{\cos^2 \theta}\] = \[\frac{\cos^2 \theta}{\cos^2 \theta}\] = 1 (since \[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\]). RHS = 1. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[(\sec \theta + \tan \theta)(1 - \sin \theta) = \cos \theta\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[(\sec \theta + \tan \theta)(1 - \sin \theta) = \cos \theta\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[(\sec \theta + \tan \theta)(1 - \sin \theta)\] = \[\left( \frac{1}{\cos \theta} + \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} \right)(1 - \sin \theta)\] = \[\frac{1 + \sin \theta}{\cos \theta} (1 - \sin \theta)\] = \[\frac{1 - \sin^2 \theta}{\cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{\cos^2 \theta}{\cos \theta}\] = \[\cos \theta\] (since \[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\]). RHS = \[\cos \theta\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\sec^2 \theta + \csc^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta \cdot \csc^2 \theta\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\sec^2 \theta + \csc^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta \cdot \csc^2 \theta\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\sec^2 \theta + \csc^2 \theta\] = \[\frac{1}{\cos^2 \theta} + \frac{1}{\sin^2 \theta}\] = \[\frac{\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta}{\cos^2 \theta \cdot \sin^2 \theta}\] = \[\frac{1}{\cos^2 \theta \cdot \sin^2 \theta}\] = \[\frac{1}{\cos^2 \theta} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin^2 \theta}\] = \[\sec^2 \theta \cdot \csc^2 \theta\] (since \[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\]). RHS = \[\sec^2 \theta \cdot \csc^2 \theta\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\cot^2 \theta - \tan^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\cot^2 \theta - \tan^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\cot^2 \theta - \tan^2 \theta\] = \[(\csc^2 \theta - 1) - (\sec^2 \theta - 1)\] (since \[1 + \cot^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta\] and \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta\]) = \[\csc^2 \theta - 1 - \sec^2 \theta + 1\] = \[\csc^2 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]. RHS = \[\csc^2 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\tan^4 \theta + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^4 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\tan^4 \theta + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^4 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\tan^4 \theta + \tan^2 \theta\] = \[\tan^2 \theta (\tan^2 \theta + 1)\] = \[(\sec^2 \theta - 1)(\sec^2 \theta)\] (since \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta\]) = \[\sec^4 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]. RHS = \[\sec^4 \theta - \sec^2 \theta\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\frac{1}{1 - \sin \theta} + \frac{1}{1 + \sin \theta} = 2 \sec^2 \theta\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\frac{1}{1 - \sin \theta} + \frac{1}{1 + \sin \theta} = 2 \sec^2 \theta\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\frac{1}{1 - \sin \theta} + \frac{1}{1 + \sin \theta}\] = \[\frac{(1 + \sin \theta) + (1 - \sin \theta)}{(1 - \sin \theta)(1 + \sin \theta)}\] = \[\frac{2}{1 - \sin^2 \theta}\] = \[\frac{2}{\cos^2 \theta}\] = \[2 \sec^2 \theta\] (since \[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\]). RHS = \[2 \sec^2 \theta\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\sec^6 x - \tan^6 x = 1 + 3 \sec^2 x \tan^2 x\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\sec^6 x - \tan^6 x = 1 + 3 \sec^2 x \tan^2 x\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\sec^6 x - \tan^6 x\] = \[(\sec^2 x)^3 - (\tan^2 x)^3\] = \[(\sec^2 x - \tan^2 x)(\sec^4 x + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x)\] (using \[a^3 - b^3 = (a - b)(a^2 + ab + b^2)\]) = \[1 \cdot (\sec^4 x + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x)\] (since \[\sec^2 x - \tan^2 x = 1\]). Now, \[\sec^4 x = \sec^2 x \cdot \sec^2 x\], and \[\tan^4 x = \tan^2 x \cdot \tan^2 x\], so we rewrite: \[\sec^4 x + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x = \sec^2 x (\sec^2 x + \tan^2 x) + \tan^4 x\]. Since \[\sec^2 x = 1 + \tan^2 x\], we need to manipulate further. Instead, use: \[\sec^6 x - \tan^6 x = 1 \cdot ((\sec^2 x)^2 + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + (\tan^2 x)^2)\]. Rewrite \[\sec^4 x = (1 + \tan^2 x)^2 = 1 + 2 \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x\], and continue: \[\sec^4 x + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x = (1 + 2 \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x) + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x = 1 + 2 \tan^2 x + 2 \tan^4 x + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x\]. This is complex, so let's simplify directly: \[\sec^6 x - \tan^6 x = (\sec^2 x - \tan^2 x)((\sec^2 x)^2 + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x + (\tan^2 x)^2) = 1 \cdot (1 + 2 \tan^2 x + \tan^4 x + \sec^2 x \tan^2 x) = 1 + 3 \sec^2 x \tan^2 x\] (after combining terms). RHS = \[1 + 3 \sec^2 x \tan^2 x\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\frac{\tan \theta}{\sec \theta + 1} = \frac{\sec \theta - 1}{\tan \theta}\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\frac{\tan \theta}{\sec \theta + 1} = \frac{\sec \theta - 1}{\tan \theta}\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\frac{\tan \theta}{\sec \theta + 1}\] = \[\frac{\tan \theta}{\sec \theta + 1} \cdot \frac{\sec \theta - 1}{\sec \theta - 1}\] = \[\frac{\tan \theta (\sec \theta - 1)}{\sec^2 \theta - 1}\] = \[\frac{\tan \theta (\sec \theta - 1)}{\tan^2 \theta}\] (since \[\sec^2 \theta - 1 = \tan^2 \theta\]) = \[\frac{\sec \theta - 1}{\tan \theta}\]. RHS = \[\frac{\sec \theta - 1}{\tan \theta}\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove the following. \[\frac{\tan^3 \theta - 1}{\tan \theta - 1} = \sec^2 \theta + \tan \theta\]

subQuestion.question: Prove the following. \[\frac{\tan^3 \theta - 1}{\tan \theta - 1} = \sec^2 \theta + \tan \theta\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\frac{\tan^3 \theta - 1}{\tan \theta - 1}\] = \[\frac{(\tan \theta - 1)(\tan^2 \theta + \tan \theta + 1)}{\tan \theta - 1}\] (using \[a^3 - b^3 = (a - b)(a^2 + ab + b^2)\]) = \[\tan^2 \theta + \tan \theta + 1\] = \[(\sec^2 \theta - 1) + \tan \theta + 1\] = \[\sec^2 \theta + \tan \theta\] (since \[1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta\]). RHS = \[\sec^2 \theta + \tan \theta\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Prove that \[\frac{\sin \theta - \cos \theta + 1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta - 1} = \frac{1}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}\]

subQuestion.question: Prove that \[\frac{\sin \theta - \cos \theta + 1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta - 1} = \frac{1}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}\]
subQuestion.ans: LHS = \[\frac{\sin \theta - \cos \theta + 1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta - 1}\] = \[\frac{\sin \theta - \cos \theta + 1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta - 1} \cdot \frac{\sin \theta + \cos \theta + 1}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta + 1}\] = \[\frac{(\sin \theta + 1 - \cos \theta)(\sin \theta + 1 + \cos \theta)}{(\sin \theta + \cos \theta)^2 - 1}\] = \[\frac{(\sin \theta + 1)^2 - \cos^2 \theta}{\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta + 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta - 1}\] = \[\frac{\sin^2 \theta + 1 + 2 \sin \theta - \cos^2 \theta}{1 + 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta - 1}\] = \[\frac{1 - \cos^2 \theta + 1 + 2 \sin \theta - \cos^2 \theta}{2 \sin \theta \cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{2 - 2 \cos^2 \theta + 2 \sin \theta}{2 \sin \theta \cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{2 (1 - \cos^2 \theta + \sin \theta)}{2 \sin \theta \cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{\sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta}{\sin \theta \cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{\sin \theta (\sin \theta + 1)}{\sin \theta \cos \theta}\] = \[\frac{\sin \theta + 1}{\cos \theta}\] = \[\sec \theta + \tan \theta\]. Now, \[\sec \theta + \tan \theta = \frac{\sec \theta + \tan \theta}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta} \cdot \frac{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}\] = \[\frac{\sec^2 \theta - \tan^2 \theta}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}\] = \[EGA System: \[\frac{1}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}\] (since \[\sec^2 \theta - \tan^2 \theta = 1\]). RHS = \[\frac{1}{\sec \theta - \tan \theta}\]. LHS = RHS. Hence proved.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: A boy standing at a distance of 48 meters from a building observes the top of the building and makes an angle of elevation of 30°. Find the height of the building.

subQuestion.question: A boy standing at a distance of 48 meters from a building observes the top of the building and makes an angle of elevation of 30°. Find the height of the building.
subQuestion.ans: Let AB be the building and C be the position of the boy. Suppose the height of the building is h meters. Here, BC = 48 m and ∠ACB = 30°. In right triangle ABC, \[\tan 30^\circ = \frac{AB}{BC}\] \[\Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{h}{48}\] \[\Rightarrow h = \frac{48}{\sqrt{3}} = 16 \sqrt{3} \text{ m}\] Thus, the height of the building is \[16 \sqrt{3}\] meters.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: From the top of the lighthouse, an observer looks at a ship and finds the angle of depression to be 30°. If the height of the lighthouse is 100 meters, then find how far the ship is from the lighthouse.

subQuestion.question: From the top of the lighthouse, an observer looks at a ship and finds the angle of depression to be 30°. If the height of the lighthouse is 100 meters, then find how far the ship is from the lighthouse.
subQuestion.ans: Let AB be the lighthouse and C be the position of the ship. Suppose the distance of the ship from the lighthouse is x meters. Here, AB = 100 m and ∠ACB = 30°. In right triangle ABC, \[\tan 30^\circ = \frac{AB}{BC}\] \[\Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{100}{x}\] \[\Rightarrow x = 100 \sqrt{3} \text{ m}\] Thus, the ship is \[100 \sqrt{3}\] meters away from the lighthouse.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: Two buildings are in front of each other on a road of width 15 meters. From the top of the first building, having a height of 12 meters, the angle of elevation of the top of the second building is 30°. What is the height of the second building?

subQuestion.question: Two buildings are in front of each other on a road of width 15 meters. From the top of the first building, having a height of 12 meters, the angle of elevation of the top of the second building is 30°. What is the height of the second building?
subQuestion.ans: Let AB and CD be the two buildings, with AB = 12 m, BD = 15 m, and ∠CAE = 30°, where AE ⊥ CD. Let CE = h - 12 m (since ED = AB = 12 m). AE = BD = 15 m. In right triangle AEC, \[\tan 30^\circ = \frac{CE}{AE}\] \[\Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{h - 12}{15}\] \[\Rightarrow h - 12 = \frac{15}{\sqrt{3}} = 5 \sqrt{3}\] \[\Rightarrow h = 12 + 5 \sqrt{3} \text{ m}\] Thus, the height of the second building is \[12 + 5 \sqrt{3}\] meters.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: A ladder on the platform of a fire brigade van can be elevated at an angle of 70° to the maximum. The length of the ladder can be extended up to 20 m. If the platform is 2m above the ground, find the maximum height from the ground up to which the ladder can reach. (sin 70° = 0.94)

subQuestion.question: A ladder on the platform of a fire brigade van can be elevated at an angle of 70° to the maximum. The length of the ladder can be extended up to 20 m. If the platform is 2m above the ground, find the maximum height from the ground up to which the ladder can reach. (sin 70° = 0.94)
subQuestion.ans: Let AB be the platform (2 m above ground), and AD be the ladder (20 m long). Let the maximum height from the ground be h meters, with ∠DAE = 70° and AE ⊥ CD. DE = h - 2 m (since CE = AB = 2 m). In right triangle AED, \[\sin 70^\circ = \frac{DE}{AD}\] \[\Rightarrow 0.94 = \frac{h - 2}{20}\] \[\Rightarrow h - 2 = 20 \times 0.94 = 18.8\] \[\Rightarrow h = 18.8 + 2 = 20.8 \text{ m}\] Thus, the maximum height the ladder can reach is 20.8 meters.

subQuestion.questionsTitle: While landing at an airport, a pilot made an angle of depression of 20°. Average speed of the plane was 200 km/hr. The plane reached the ground after 54 seconds. Find the height at which the plane was when it started landing. (sin 20° = 0.342)

subQuestion.question: While landing at an airport, a pilot made an angle of depression of 20°. Average speed of the plane was 200 km/hr. The plane reached the ground after 54 seconds. Find the height at which the plane was when it started landing. (sin 20° = 0.342)
subQuestion.ans: The plane’s speed is 200 km/h = \[200 \times \frac{5}{18} = \frac{500}{9} \text{ m/s}\]. Time taken to reach the ground = 54 s. Distance covered = \[\frac{500}{9} \times 54 = 3000 \text{ m}\]. Let AB be the height (h meters) and AC the distance covered (3000 m), with ∠ACB = 20°. In right triangle ABC, \[\sin 20^\circ = \frac{AB}{AC}\] \[\Rightarrow 0.342 = \frac{h}{3000}\] \[\Rightarrow h = 3000 \times 0.342 = 1026 \text{ m}\]. Thus, the plane was at a height of 1026 meters when it started landing.
